advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMODORE WATCHES!</strong></font><br><blockquote>While manufacturing and selling calculators in 1977, Commodore sold wristwatches.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Chuck Guzis</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right arrow, advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Redesigned front panel. Totally synchronous logic design. Same switch and LED arrangement as original Altair 8800. New back.lit Duralith (laminated plastic and mylar, bonded to aluminum) dress panel with multi.color graphics. New longer, flat toggle switches. Five new functions stored on front panel PROM inc1uding: DISPLAY ACCUMULATOR (displays contents of accumulator), LOAD ACCUMULATOR (loads contents of the 8 data switches (A7.AO) into accumulator), OUTPUT ACCUMULATOR (Outputs contents of accumulator to I/O device addressed by the upper 8 address switches), INPUT ACCUMULATOR (inputs to the accumulator from the I/O device), and SLOW (causes program execution at a rate of about 5 cycles per second for program debugging). <br><br> Two, 34 conductor ribbon cable assemblies. Connects front panel board to front panel interface board. Eliminates need for complicated front panel/bus wiring. <br><br> New front panel interface board buffers all lines to and from 8800b bus. <br><br> Rugged, commercial grade Optima cabinet. <br><br> Full 18 slot motherboard. <br><br> New CPU board with 8080A microprocessor and Intel 8224 clock generator and 8216 bus drivers. Clock pulse widths and phasing as well as frequency are crystal controlled. Compatible with all current Altair 8800 software and hardware!. <br><br> New, heavy duty power supply: +8 volts at 18 amps, + 18 volts at 2 amps, -18 volts at 2 amps. 110 volt or 220 volt operation (50/60 Hz). Primary tapped for either high or low line operation.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>A pretty secretary, a clean office with nice colours, and a computer working without any printer, cables, disks... Does it really sound realistic to you ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NICE AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As computing was a serious and professional subject, the humorus adverts was rare in 1983.<br> This one said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> When I told my Dad about NEC TREK, NEC's new personal computer, he wanted one right away.<br><br> I told him it has 10 programmable function keys; high powered graphic capabilities, powerful Microsoft BASIC included, and a 8-octave programmable musical tone generator.<br><br> He said it has lot of 'fun games'. <br><br> I told him how its memory storage can interface with cassette diskette or cartridge, and how it has a wide variety of of sophisticated software available - important things like financial management package...<br><br> He just challenged me to a game of Protector.<br><br> That's my Dad. I love him, but sometimes I wish he could understand how a kid feels.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD. #3 (NOV. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The BBC Master Compact's educational software, takes children from their first grasp of words and numbers to A-level and beyond.<br> In 84% of U.K. schools, children are already growing up with BBC micros.<br> With a BBC Master Compact at home, your child's ability with computers will progress in leaps and bounds... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert tried to convince computers newcomers that a pocket computer could do the same as a desktop computer...<br><br><font color="#666666"> Now Texas Instruments brings you a cordless compact computer that solves the same sort of problems as the Apple or IBM Personal Computer...<br><br> ...For most personal computer tasks, its 6K RAM and 34K ROM are ample...</font></blockquote>

computer.colors: 16 (8 colours in normal or bright modes)
computer.cpu: MMN-80 an East European clone version of the Z80-A
computer.description:
Few information about this computer, a Romanian Sinclair ZX-Spectrum clone made from 1988 by Electronica CIE and sold only in Romania in blue or red case colour version. In fact, the colors only differed on the keyboard marquee, the case color being the same. On the red version the background of the keys is darker than on the blue version.
The CIP-03 had a built-in Spectrum compatible BASIC interpreter in ROM. But instead of the original Sinclair copyright text at boot, it shows simply a "BASIC S" string on the center of the bottom line on the screen.
The computer had no joystick interface built in, it could been however purchased separately (in contrast, other romanian Spectrum clones had built-in joystick port.) The keyboard had switches instead of the membrane of the original ZX Spectrum. Though it had a clumsy feeling while typing, it did not wear out easily. The computer had an internal speaker of about 0.5 watts which gave a very loud noise while loading programs, and there were no way to control the volume...
Apparently the CIP-03 is the most common of all Romanian ZX Spectrum clones.
There was another version called CIP-02 which had only 2 KB ROM containing a copy utility program. The advantage was that the RAM available for copying was 60 KB, more than enough for copying a full 48k program.
The BASIC interpreter was available on cassette tape and needed to be loaded each time the computer was powered on (but not reseted as the 0-16 KB area was protected from interrupts).
__________
Contributors: Sz?sz Edu?rd Istv?n (info)
Calin Popescu, the designer of the CIP-03 sent us this line: I was the engineer who led the entire process - from design to manufacture - of this Spectrum clone at Electronica Bucuresti. I think we manufactured about 15000 units until I left Romania in 1993. The production continued for a while after that but I do not have more info. I do have own one protptype.
Geroge Sauciuc from Romania adds: The CIP-03 was used in public schools, for informatics classes. this mashine was delivery with tape recorder, external power supply unit, and with one programs tape (all Romanian programs because at this period, all programs must be made in Romania).
Liviu A. Stefanescu reports: I am the RF designer ( electrical schematics final version after few revisions, PCB prototyping, several pilot runs, volume production) of the UHF modulator used in the HC models 85 and later. The UHF modulator was transforming the video composite signal into a TV channel signal specific to the standard D/K, usually one of the channels 25..30 , manufactured by I. Electronica was similar to the one used for computers HC85 and later HC models produced by ICE-Pipera. The modulator was a stand alone module that was being added on the Main board as needed. Some versions were not delivered with TV modulator.
computer.name: CIP-03
computer.ports: Tape recorder, Expansion bus, Composite video, TV aerial, AC adaptor
computer.power: External power supply unit 5V 3A Central polarity: Plus

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> RED VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The red version with the impressive power supply unit</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Power supply jack<br> <b>(2)</b> Expansion/Bus connector<br> <b>(3)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug<br> <b>(4)</b> Composite video monitor DIN plug<br> <b>(5)</b> RF modulator output<br> <b>(6)</b> Reset switch </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each key features the same functions as the original ZX-Spectrum</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UNCOVERED KEYBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>A true mechanical keyboard, much more convenient for quick typing than the original Spectrum one, even if key switches are real simple and so is the 'feeling'.<br><br> Keys are covered with a transparent red (red version) or black (blue version) plastic cover.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CIP MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>About 20 standard chips (most 74-family) are here used in place of the Spectrum ULA custom chip. <br><br> <b>(1)</b> RF modulator. Produces TV aerial compatible signals<br> <b>(2)</b> System Reset switch<br> <b>(3)</b> Composite video monitor DIN plug<br> <b>(4)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug<br> <b>(5)</b> Keyboard connector<br> <b>(6)</b> MMN-80 processor (Z80-A clone)<br> <b>(7)</b> Expansion/Bus connector<br> <b>(8)</b> Power supply jack plug<br> <b>(9)</b> 16 KB EPROM holding the Spectrum BASIC interpreter<br> <b>(10)</b> 64 KB RAM chips (East European MMN 4164) </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD CLOSE-UP #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>RF modulator area. All the chips used were produced in East European countries. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> USER MANUAL COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>User manual explains all the Spectrum BASIC commands with many example programs, as well as major internal memory addresses meaning. Le BASIC interpreter is called S-BASIC.<br> 'calculator pentru instruire' means 'computer for teaching'</blockquote>
